Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Socio-Spatial Factors Influencing Prenatal Care Availability, Access, and Use

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores issues related to immigrant health care through an investigation of the changing socio-spatial relationships (e.g. political, economic, socio-cultural, and geographic) that shape immigrant women's health during pregnancy. Using the case of Haitian migrant farm workers in Immokalee, FL, this research investigates the availability, provision, utilization, and accessibility of prenatal care to immigrant women in order to understand not only the specific issues that these women face in trying to maintain their health during pregnancy, but also the broader political, economic, and social processes that contribute to immigrant women's health disparities across the United States. The research is expected to fill scholarly and clinical gaps in understanding the socio-spatial factors influencing immigrant health, the politics of immigrant health care, rural and minority health disparities, and the emerging impacts of the Affordable Care Act on the health care system more broadly. It also explores the methodological possibilities offered by qualitative GIS to health researchers and planners by producing dynamic maps that show the complex relationship between gender, politics, economics, and health care.

Using a critical medical geography framework, the researchers draw from interdisciplinary literatures on healthcare, intersectionality, immigration, and critical GIS. The project has four interrelated aims: First, using archival research and mapping, it explores how the changing politics of immigrant health (and the notion of "deservingness") affect the health care landscape in the United States. Second, it uses interview data from health care providers to explain how the changing politics of immigrant health care affects the provision of care for immigrant women. Third, using feminist qualitative GIS and multi-session in-depth interviewing, the project investigates immigrant women's experiences of the health care system, as well as how these experiences influence where and how they utilize health care services. Finally, it identifies the socio-spatial barriers that immigrant women face in accessing care in an effort to improve health care accessibility in the community.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Immigrant health care access is a hot topic in American political discourse.  In the state of Florida, the number of foreign-born individuals has steadily grown to nearly 20% of the state’s population—or 3.6 million individuals.  Changing demographics of the state have been accompanied by debate both in government and in public discourse on the financial cost of providing health services to immigrants and low-income citizens.  Health care providers increasingly find themselves in a paradoxical situation in which they are expected to protect and promote the health of an increasingly diverse population at the same time that they receive limited support for work with immigrants.  The result is a highly ineffective immigrant health care system that leaves many living in Florida without the health care they want or need.   

This project explored the issue of immigrant health care through an investigation of the changing socio-spatial relationships impacting health care in Immokalee, Florida—a rural agricultural community in southwest Florida with a large immigrant population.  Using a case study approach, this research investigated four aspects of health care delivery (availability, provision, utilization, and accessibility) from multiple perspectives to understand the issues administrators, providers, and Haitian women face in trying to maintain Haitian health in a time of change in the American health care system.  We used a combination of quantitative, qualitative, and multi-scalar policy research.   NSF funding was used to live and work in the study area for two years, during which time the investigators conducted interviews with 30 Haitian women on their experiences of healthcare and the barriers they face in accessing appropriate care using a local translator/cultural broker; completed interviews with 10 healthcare providers and administrators who work in or near Immokalee on their experiences of health system changes and the provision of care to Haitian women; visited several healthcare facilities in and around Immokalee that serve a large immigrant population; and participated in teaching and service-related activities relating to public health and immigrant health.

Based on qualitative data and policy research, the early project results show that law and policy impacts funding and finances for health providers, which then impacts providers and patients.  For example, (1) policies relating to both healthcare and immigration --such as Medicaid eligibility for immigrants and/or low-income persons - have a noticeable impact on the ability of healthcare facilities to provide the types of care needed in the community through their ability to remain financially solvent.  Health providers in Immokalee -- a rural, resource-poor community -- face many of the same challenges as we see across the health system, including challenges in staffing, funding, social distance, compliance, and overall difficulties in improving health outcomes.  Providers must negotiate limited resources and these other challenges to provide quality care.  (2) This also shapes the ability of immigrants to obtain the health care services they need - those with Medicaid were much more likely to utilize primary health care services than those without insurance coverage, though many women utilized the emergency room at some point to receive non-urgent care, regardless of insurance status.  The women interviewed stated non-financial barriers to care as well, including geographic and language/cultural barriers.  Additional results are expected in the next 6 months as the dissertation is completed.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its relevance to a range of contemporary scholarly interests, including the expanding field of medical/health geography, qualitative GIS, health care planning, the political economy of health care, and health disparities.  There is significant interest in the factors that contribute to inequities in health and health care in the United States, especially in relation to federally-designated ‘priority populations’ (including rural, low-income, im/migrant, and pregnant women) since the enactment of the Affordable Care Act.  This research contributes new theoretical insights into the socio-spatial factors influencing the health of a target population in a target area within the context of a rapidly changing immigrant health landscape. 

The broader impacts of this study can be seen in its applicability to health care practice and planning.  Though this project is a case study of this unique place and population, the researchers see connections to other immigrant groups in the U.S. through an understanding of how the politics of immigrant health care—and the notion of ‘deservingness’—impact the availability, delivery, accessibility, and utilization of health care by immigrants.  Second, the project assists in the production of knowledge with a relatively understudied population – Haitian women, who are often discussed in clinical literature as ‘non-compliant’ -- using Haitian women’s own voices, which are often excluded from full participation in the health care decisions made by planners and providers that would directly impact their health.  The authors hope that this research can help improve the quality, efficiency, and effectiveness of health care (and potentially health outcomes as well) in Immokalee and beyond.


Last Modified: 03/30/2017
Modified by: Michele Bolduc
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Immigrant health care access is a hot topic in American political discourse. In the state of Florida, the number of foreign-born individuals has steadily grown to nearly 20% of the state?s population—or 3.6 million individuals. Changing demographics of the state have been accompanied by debate both in government and in public discourse on the financial cost of providing health services to immigrants and low-income citizens. Health care providers increasingly find themselves in a paradoxical situation in which they are expected to protect and promote the health of an increasingly diverse population at the same time that they receive limited support for work with immigrants. The result is a highly ineffective immigrant health care system that leaves many living in Florida without the health care they want or need. This project explored the issue of immigrant health care through an investigation of the changing socio-spatial relationships impacting health care in Immokalee, Florida—a rural agricultural community in southwest Florida with a large immigrant population. Using a case study approach, this research investigated four aspects of health care delivery (availability, provision, utilization, and accessibility) from multiple perspectives to understand the issues administrators, providers, and Haitian women face in trying to maintain Haitian health in a time of change in the American health care system. We used a combination of quantitative, qualitative, and multi-scalar policy research. NSF funding was used to live and work in the study area for two years, during which time the investigators conducted interviews with 30 Haitian women on their experiences of healthcare and the barriers they face in accessing appropriate care using a local translator/cultural broker; completed interviews with 10 healthcare providers and administrators who work in or near Immokalee on their experiences of health system changes and the provision of care to Haitian women; visited several healthcare facilities in and around Immokalee that serve a large immigrant population; and participated in teaching and service-related activities relating to public health and immigrant health. Based on qualitative data and policy research, the early project results show that law and policy impacts funding and finances for health providers, which then impacts providers and patients. For example, (1) policies relating to both healthcare and immigration --such as Medicaid eligibility for immigrants and/or low-income persons - have a noticeable impact on the ability of healthcare facilities to provide the types of care needed in the community through their ability to remain financially solvent. Health providers in Immokalee -- a rural, resource-poor community -- face many of the same challenges as we see across the health system, including challenges in staffing, funding, social distance, compliance, and overall difficulties in improving health outcomes. Providers must negotiate limited resources and these other challenges to provide quality care. (2) This also shapes the ability of immigrants to obtain the health care services they need - those with Medicaid were much more likely to utilize primary health care services than those without insurance coverage, though many women utilized the emergency room at some point to receive non-urgent care, regardless of insurance status. The women interviewed stated non-financial barriers to care as well, including geographic and language/cultural barriers. Additional results are expected in the next 6 months as the dissertation is completed. The intellectual merit of this project lies in its relevance to a range of contemporary scholarly interests, including the expanding field of medical/health geography, qualitative GIS, health care planning, the political economy of health care, and health disparities. There is significant interest in the factors that contribute to inequities in health and health care in the United States, especially in relation to federally-designated ?priority populations? (including rural, low-income, im/migrant, and pregnant women) since the enactment of the Affordable Care Act. This research contributes new theoretical insights into the socio-spatial factors influencing the health of a target population in a target area within the context of a rapidly changing immigrant health landscape. The broader impacts of this study can be seen in its applicability to health care practice and planning. Though this project is a case study of this unique place and population, the researchers see connections to other immigrant groups in the U.S. through an understanding of how the politics of immigrant health care—and the notion of ?deservingness?—impact the availability, delivery, accessibility, and utilization of health care by immigrants. Second, the project assists in the production of knowledge with a relatively understudied population – Haitian women, who are often discussed in clinical literature as ?non-compliant? -- using Haitian women?s own voices, which are often excluded from full participation in the health care decisions made by planners and providers that would directly impact their health. The authors hope that this research can help improve the quality, efficiency, and effectiveness of health care (and potentially health outcomes as well) in Immokalee and beyond.
